chapter.title: Management Server Installation
chapter.para:
The Cloud.com Management Server download includes everything you need to get started, except MySQL. This includes the Cloud.com software as well as dependencies. This section describes installing one or more Management Servers with one instance of MySQL, which may be on a different node from the Management Servers. The procedure for the installation is:
Prepare the operating system
Install and configure the management server
Install and configure MySQL

section.title: Operating System Preparation
section.para: The Cloud.com Management Server requires RHEL/CentOS 5.4 64 bit or later. The OS must be prepared to host the Management Server using the following steps.

note.para: NTP configuration is highly recommended. Installing and configuring ntp or chrony should be done on all hosts

listitem.para: Edit the /etc/hosts file to make sure that the Management Server has a fully-qualified host name that resolves to an IP address.

note.para: The above will make the management server, but in a production environment the host name should be configured via DNS

listitem.para: Log in as root. All the subsequent steps should be run as root.
Ensure that the SELINUX variable in /etc/selinux/config is set to permissive.
Run the following command to disable SELinux in the current session.

note.para: Performing both of the above steps is mandatory to avoid a reboot.

listitem.para: Make sure that the Management Server can reach the Internet.

section.title: Installation
section.para: This section describes the procedure for performing a single node install where the Management Server and MySQL are on a single, shared OS instance. More complicated installations are detailed in the Installation Guide

section.title: Management Server
section.para: Install the CloudStack packages. You should have a file in the form of CloudStack-NNNN.tar.gz. Untar the file and then run the install.sh script inside it:
section.programlisting:
# tar xzf CloudStack-2.2.0-1-centos.tar.gz # cd CloudStack-2.2.0-1-centos # ./install.sh Setting up the temporary repository... Cleaning Yum cache... Loaded plugins: fastestmirror 11 metadata files removed Welcome to the Cloud.com CloudStack Installer. What would you like to do?
M) Install the Management Server A) Install the Agent S) Install the Usage Monitor D) Install the database server Q) Quit
> M
section.para: Choose "M" to install the Management Server software

section.title: Database
section.para: Run install.sh again and choose "D" to install MySQL
section.programlisting:
# ./install.sh Setting up the temporary repository... Cleaning Yum cache... Loaded plugins: fastestmirror 11 metadata files removed Welcome to the Cloud.com CloudStack Installer. What would you like to do?
A) Install the Agent S) Install the Usage Monitor D) Install the database server U) Upgrade the CloudStack packages installed on this computer R) Stop any running CloudStack services and remove the CloudStack packages from this computer Q) Quit
> D
section.para: Edit the MySQL configuration (/etc/my.cnf) and insert the following lines in the [mysqld] section. You can put these lines below the datadir line.
Restart the MySQL service and configure it to start on boot
section.programlisting: # service mysqld restart # chkconfig mysqld on
section.para: Use the following script to create the cloud user on the database with a password of your choice. This script deploys the database using the credentials in the deploy-as parameters. By default on RHEL/CentOS/Fedora MySQL is installed with no root password. If you have set a password you will need to postpend that to the deploy-as parameter as in "--deploy-as=root:password
